questions.text: A 45-year-old female who recently underwent bone marrow transplantation presents with abdominal pain and swelling. The clinical features resonate with hepatic veno-occlusive disease and a transvenous hepatic biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following symptoms is NOT a part of the clinical triad of hepatic veno-occlusive disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Portal hypertension
Explanation:

  • The clinical triad of veno-occlusive disease includes tender hepatomegaly, hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice), and retention of fluid (ascites).

  • While portal hypertension can be a complication of VOD, it is not part of the clinical triad.

Hepatic veno-occlusive disease / Sinusoidal Obstruction Syndrome

Definition

Hepatic venous outflow obstruction caused by endothelial sclerosis of sublobular hepatic veins and venules

Etiology
  • The most common cause in Western countries: Bone marrow transplantation
  • Chemotherapy agents: Cytarabine, Thioguanine, Gemtuzumab, Ozogamicin
  • Immunosuppressive agents: Azathioprine
  • Consumption of bush teas: Crotalaria and Senecio (contain pyrrolizidine alkaloids)

Clinical Features (Triad)
  • Tender hepatomegaly
  • Hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice)
  • Retention of fluid (ascites)

Diagnosis

Investigation of choice: Biopsy

Management
  • SSPCS (Side-to-side portocaval shunt): Only if hepatic venous outflow obstruction with IVC sparing
  • Liver transplantation: For hepatic failure
  • Defibrotide: Improves survival

questions.text: Which of the following is a pre-sinusoidal cause of portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Schistosomiasis

Explanation:

Schistosomiasis is a pre-sinusoidal intrahepatic cause of portal hypertension.

 

The causes of portal hypertension can be classified based on the location of the obstruction:

Pre-sinusoidal

Sinusoidal

Post-sinusoidal

Extrahepatic

  • Portal vein thrombosis
  • Splenic vein thrombosis
  • Myelofibrosis
  • Arterioportal shunt
  • Tropical splenomegaly
 

Intrahepatic

  • Schistosomiasis
  • Congenital hepatic fibrosis
  • Portal infiltration (e.g., sarcoidosis)
  • Drugs and toxins
  • Cirrhosis

(Option A)
  • Hepatic vein occlusion (Budd-Chiari syndrome)
  • Veno-occlusive disease
  • Congestive cardiac failure

Which of the following vessels is involved in this condition?

Caput medusae is a clinical sign associated with portal hypertension. It occurs due to increased pressure in the portal venous system, resulting in the development of engorged veins around the umbilicus. questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with hematemesis and melena. He is hypotensive and tachycardic. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Request a CT scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Initiate fluid resuscitation

Explanation:

  • The immediate priority in managing variceal bleeding is stabilizing the patient's condition. This involves the airway, breathing, and circulation.
  • Establishing intravenous access with large-bore cannulae allows for rapid fluid resuscitation, ideally with blood transfusions, to restore circulatory volume and address hypotension.

  • Option A) While endoscopy is crucial for diagnosis and definitive treatment of variceal bleeding, it should only be performed after the patient is hemodynamically stable.
  • Option B) Proton pump inhibitors reduce gastric acid secretion but have no role in the initial management of acute variceal bleeding.
  • Option C) CT scanning can help evaluate the liver and portal vein, but it is not a priority during the initial resuscitation phase.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the image below?

choices.text: Lack of depth perception is present

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: (D) Lack of depth perception is present

Explanation:

The image is a procedure of Endoscopic sclerotherapy commonly done in the case of esophageal variceal bleeding. A double-channel endoscope equipped with a bridge is essential for performing sclerotherapy. The bridge facilitates suction during the injection process and enhances the maneuverability of the needle. The sclerosants commonly used include Sodium Tetradecyl Sulfate, ethanolamine oleate, etc.

 

Treatment of Choice to Control Bleeding:

  • Endoscopic Variceal Ligation (EVL) is preferred over endoscopic sclerotherapy for controlling bleeding from variceal hemorrhage. (Option C)
  • EVL is technically more challenging to perform but carries a lower risk of esophageal perforation compared to sclerotherapy.
  • Endoscopic sclerotherapy, while easier to perform,(Option A) has a higher risk of esophageal perforation (Option B) due to reduced depth perception during the procedure. (Option D)

questions.text: Identify the tube shown in the following image used in the management of portal hypertension.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Sengstaken-Blakemore tube

Explanation:

The Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used to manage esophageal variceal bleeding.

  • The tube is inserted through the nose or mouth and carefully advanced into the stomach.
  • Once in position, the balloons are sequentially inflated to apply pressure on the bleeding varices, effectively controlling hemorrhage.
  • This intervention is temporary and used in the emergency setting until definitive treatments, such as endoscopic procedures, can be performed.

 

The tube has 3 lumens and 2 inflatable balloons:

Lumens:

  • Gastric Aspiration Lumen: This lumen allows for the drainage of gastric contents. It helps to monitor and manage any bleeding from the stomach.
  • Gastric Balloon Lumen: This lumen is connected to the gastric balloon and is used to inflate it with air or saline, anchoring the tube in place within the stomach.
  • Esophageal Balloon Lumen: This lumen is connected to the esophageal balloon and is used to inflate it, applying pressure to the esophageal varices to stop bleeding.

Balloons:

  • Gastric Balloon: Positioned in the stomach, this balloon is inflated to anchor the tube and to apply pressure to the area of bleeding if necessary.
  • Esophageal Balloon: This balloon is inflated within the esophagus to exert pressure directly on the bleeding varices, helping to control hemorrhage.

  • Option B: The Minnesota tube is similar to the Sengstaken-Blakemore tube but with an additional lumen for the suction of esophageal secretions.
  • Option C: The Linton-Nachlas tube is used for the decompression of the stomach and the prevention of aspiration in cases of massive upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. It is not commonly used for esophageal varices but rather for general decompression and bleeding control in the stomach.
  • Option D: Nasogastric (Ryle's) tube is used for gastric decompression, feeding, and administering medications. It is not designed for controlling esophageal variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with refractory ascites secondary to cirrhosis undergoes Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt placement. Two days post-procedure, the patient develops severe dyspnea, peripheral edema, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. A Doppler ultrasound reveals a patent shunt. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Right heart failure

Explanation:

  • Post-TIPSS, the increased preload from the diverted blood flow can overwhelm the right heart, leading to right heart failure.
  • This presents as severe dyspnea, peripheral edema, jugular venous distension, and hypotension.
  • The management includes the use of diuretics to reduce fluid overload.

TIPSS (Transjugular Intrahepatic Porto Systemic Shunt)

  • It is a nonselective shunt used to treat complications of portal hypertension.
  • The liver is accessed through the Jugular vein and the stent is placed to create a channel between the right Hepatic vein and the right branch of the portal vein.
  • Reduces portal pressure by diverting blood flow.

 

Indications

Contraindications
  • Variceal bleeding
  • Refractory ascites
  • Hepatic hydrothorax
  • Budd Chiari Syndrome
  • Portal Hypertensive gastropathy
  • Severe hepatic encephalopathy
  • Severe heart failure
  • Severe pulmonary hypertension
  • Uncontrolled systemic infection
  • Polycystic liver disease

Option B:

  • The hepatorenal syndrome occurs in advanced liver disease characterized by renal failure due to altered renal perfusion without structural kidney damage.
  • It presents with renal dysfunction (e.g., oliguria, elevated serum creatinine) rather than severe dyspnea, peripheral edema, and jugular venous distension.

Option C:

  • Pulmonary hypertension can occur in liver disease but is less likely to cause acute severe dyspnea, peripheral edema, and jugular venous distension immediately post-TIPSS.
  • This condition usually develops gradually and presents with symptoms like fatigue, chest pain, and dyspnea on exertion.

Option D: Porto-pulmonary hypertension develops over time and is characterized by increased pulmonary artery pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following complications is most likely to occur after the creation of a side-to-side portocaval shunt (SSPCS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Encephalopathy

Explanation:

  • Encephalopathy is a common complication following the creation of a non-selective shunt like the side-to-side portocaval shunt (SSPCS).
  • This is because the shunt allows portal blood which contains toxins, to bypass the liver and enter the systemic circulation directly, leading to hepatic encephalopathy.

 

Non-Selective Shunts:

  • Non-selective shunts are surgical procedures used to manage portal hypertension by diverting blood flow from the portal venous system directly into the systemic circulation, bypassing the liver.
  • This reduces portal pressure and decreases complications like variceal bleeding.
  • However, they also reduce hepatic blood flow, potentially leading to liver ischemia and worsening hepatic function.

 

Side-to-side portocaval Shunt (SSPCS) involves a side-to-side anastomosis between the portal vein and the inferior vena cava.

  • Used for conditions such as Budd-Chiari syndrome, veno-occlusive disease, and refractory ascites.
  • Most widely performed shunt due to its effectiveness in reducing portal pressure.
  • High risk of hepatic encephalopathy due to the diversion of blood away from the liver, reducing its detoxification capacity.

 

Other Non-Selective Shunts:

  1. Eck Fistula is an end-to-side portocaval shunt where the portal vein is divided, and its proximal part is sutured to the inferior vena cava.
  2. Interposition Grafts - A vascular graft is used to connect the portal vein to the systemic circulation.
    • Types include portocaval, mesocaval (superior mesenteric vein to inferior vena cava), and mesorenal (superior mesenteric vein to left renal vein) grafts.
    • Used when a direct shunt is not feasible or preferred.

IVC - Inferior Vena Cava; P/C - Porto-caval; M/C - Meso-caval; M/R - Meso-renal; PV - Portal Vein; SMV - Superior Mesenteric Vein; SV - Splenic Vein;

Left RV - Left Renal Vein

  1. Proximal Splenorenal Shunt (PSRS) or Linton’s Shunt
    • After a splenectomy, the proximal part of the splenic vein is sutured to the left renal vein.

Option B: While renal failure can occur in advanced liver disease, it is not a direct complication of SSPCS. Renal failure is more associated with hepatorenal syndrome in the context of cirrhosis and severe liver dysfunction.

Option C: SSPCS is designed to reduce portal pressure and prevent variceal bleeding. Therefore, recurrent variceal bleeding is less likely to occur after the procedure.

Option D: While possible, portal vein thrombosis is not the most common complication of SSPCS.

questions.text: Which selective shunt procedure is associated with the preservation of portal perfusion to the liver while effectively decompressing varices?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Distal splenorenal shunt (DSRS)

Explanation:

 

Selective Shunts:

Selective shunts are designed to divert blood from specific parts of the portal system, preserving some hepatic portal perfusion and reducing the risk of hepatic encephalopathy.

  1. Distal Splenorenal Shunt (DSRS) or Warren Shunt
    • The distal part of the splenic vein is anastomosed to the left renal vein.
    • Selectively decompresses the spleen and gastroesophageal junction varices while maintaining hepatic portal flow.
    • Lower risk of encephalopathy compared to non-selective shunts.

  1. Inokuchi Shunt
    • Involves an interposition graft between the left gastric vein and the inferior vena cava.
    • Used for selectively draining the gastroesophageal junction, particularly in patients with gastroesophageal varices.



 

Option B: Proximal splenorenal shunt (PSRS), after splenectomy, connects the proximal splenic vein to the left renal vein but does not specifically focus on preserving portal perfusion to the liver.

Option C: Side-to-side portocaval shunt (SSPCS) diverts a significant portion of portal blood flow to the inferior vena cava, reducing portal pressure but not preserving liver perfusion.

Option D: Interposition grafts are non-selective shunts that can be used to connect the portal vein to the systemic circulation.

questions.text: In a patient with Budd Chiari Syndrome, which of the following imaging findings is most indicative of chronic disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Enlarged caudate lobe

Explanation:

  • The enlarged caudate lobe is a hallmark of chronic Budd Chiari Syndrome.
  • The caudate lobe has its own venous drainage directly into the inferior vena cava, allowing it to remain viable and potentially enlarge when the rest of the liver is affected by venous outflow obstruction.

Budd-Chiari Syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow obstruction, leading to liver congestion, ischemia, and damage.

  1. Etiology:
    • The most common cause is hepatic venous thrombosis. Other causes include inferior vena cava obstruction.
    • Risk Factors: Polycythemia vera, thrombophilic disorders, and malignancies are significant risk factors.
  2. Clinical Features
    • The characteristic triad includes ascites, hepatomegaly, and abdominal pain.
    • Jaundice, encephalopathy, anorexia, and fatigue may occur if hepatic failure develops.
  3. Diagnosis and Treatment
    • Venography is the investigation of choice, showing spider web collaterals if the hepatic veins are involved, or vena cavography if the inferior vena cava is obstructed.
    • Treatment includes anticoagulants, thrombolysis (if within the window period), and surgical intervention. In cases of liver failure, liver transplantation is the treatment of choice.

 

Option B: Ascites can occur in both acute and chronic Budd Chiari Syndrome and is not specific to the chronic stage of the disease.

Option C: While hepatic vein thrombosis is a key feature of Budd-Chiari Syndrome, it can be present in both acute and chronic stages and does not specifically indicate chronicity.

Option D: Splenomegaly is a common finding due to portal hypertension but can be seen in both acute and chronic phases, thus not specifically indicative of chronic disease.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. He has no history of liver disease, jaundice, or ascites. Physical examination reveals moderate splenomegaly but no hepatomegaly. Doppler ultrasound of the abdomen shows obstruction at the confluence of the splenic vein and the superior mesenteric vein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Extrahepatic Portal Vein Obstruction (EHPVO)

Explanation:
Extrahepatic Portal Vein Obstruction (EHPVO) is characterized by obstruction of the portal vein outside the liver, commonly at the confluence of the splenic vein and superior mesenteric vein. It is often seen in younger patients 1st to 2nd decade of life and can present with gastrointestinal bleeding and splenomegaly without signs of liver disease.

  • Option A: Cirrhosis typically presents with signs of liver disease, such as jaundice, ascites, and hepatomegaly, none of which are present in this patient.
  • Option B: Non-Cirrhotic Portal Fibrosis (NCPF) involves the intrahepatic branches of the portal vein and typically presents in the 2nd to 4th decades of life, with more severe splenomegaly. It is associated with certain substances such as Vinyl chloride, Arsenic, and Copper.
  • Option D: Budd-Chiari Syndrome involves obstruction of the hepatic veins, often presenting with hepatomegaly, ascites, and liver dysfunction, which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of left upper quadrant abdominal pain and nausea. He has a history of chronic pancreatitis due to alcohol abuse. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the left upper quadrant and splenomegaly. Abdominal CT scan without contrast shows a thrombus in the splenic vein. What type of varices are likely to be seen on endoscopic examination?

choices.text: Esophageal and gastric varices, with esophageal predominant

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Gastric varices

Explanation:
This clinical scenario is typical of splenic vein thrombosis (SVT), a condition often associated with chronic pancreatitis. The patient's history of chronic pancreatitis, left upper quadrant pain, splenomegaly, and the CT finding of a thrombus in the splenic vein all point to this diagnosis.

Splenic vein thrombosis predominantly shows gastric varices on endoscopy.

Splenic vein thrombosis

Etiology
  • Pancreatic disorders (most common):
  • Acute or chronic pancreatitis
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Abdominal trauma or surgery
  • Hypercoagulable states

Pathophysiology
  • Obstruction of splenic vein leading to increased pressure in splenic circulation
  • Development of collateral circulation (left-sided portal hypertension)
  • Formation of gastric (predominantly) and esophageal varices
  • Splenomegaly due to congestion

Diagnosis
  • CT or MRI showing splenic vein occlusion
  • Endoscopic ultrasound
  • Angiography (less commonly used)
  • Clinical signs: splenomegaly, gastric varices, normal liver function

Treatment
  • Treat underlying cause (e.g., pancreatitis)
  • Anticoagulant therapy using LMWH
  • Splenectomy for symptomatic patients or those with bleeding varices
  • Endoscopic management of bleeding varices

Option A: Esophageal varices are more commonly associated with cirrhosis and generalized portal hypertension, rather than isolated splenic vein thrombosis.

Option C: While it's possible to have both esophageal and gastric varices, the predominance of esophageal varices is more characteristic of portal hypertension (as seen in cirrhosis) rather than splenic vein thrombosis.

Option D: Duodenal varices are rare and usually associated with generalized portal hypertension or portal vein thrombosis, not isolated splenic vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis presents with recurrent esophageal variceal bleeding that has not responded to endoscopic treatments. The patient is scheduled for a Sugiura procedure. Which of the following components is NOT part of the Sugiura procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Intraesophageal portacaval shunt
Explanation:
The Sugiura procedure includes:

  • Splenectomy
  • Esophagogastric devascularization
  • Esophageal transection

Sugiura procedure is used to manage recurrent esophageal variceal bleeding that does not improve on conventional treatment protocols.

The Sugiura procedure is a surgical technique used to manage bleeding esophageal varices, often due to portal hypertension from liver cirrhosis. It involves two main components:

1. Esophageal Devascularization: This part of the procedure involves surgically cutting off the blood supply to the esophagus to reduce the pressure in the varices and prevent bleeding.

2. Gastroesophageal Decompression: In this step, the procedure may also include diverting blood flow away from the esophageal varices, such as creating a shunt or performing other decompression techniques

questions.text: A 48-year-old male is diagnosed with portal hypertension. Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) measurements are taken to assess the severity of his portal hypertension. Based on the prognostic values of HVPG, what are the cut-off HVPG values for clinically significant portal hypertension and increased risk of acute variceal bleeding respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. ≥10 mm Hg, ≥12 mm Hg

Explanation:

  • Clinically significant portal hypertension is defined by an HVPG of ≥10 mm Hg.

  • HVPG of ≥12 mm Hg is associated with an increased risk of acute variceal bleeding.

  • These cut-off values are used to evaluate the prognosis of patients with chronic liver disease and portal hypertension.
